title: Hades II
summary: The sequel to the award-winning rogue-like, featuring Melinoë's quest through the Underworld with expanded mechanics and new gods.
review: Hades 2 is easily one of the coolest and most unique hack-and-slash platformers I’ve ever played. As someone who loves Greek mythology, I was immediately drawn in, and the game didn’t disappoint. Everything—from the character attributes to the boons you collect—fits together beautifully. The soundtrack is absolutely incredible, the bosses are awesome, and overall, it’s just a really fun game.

title: Baldur's Gate 3
summary: A modern CRPG that revives deep roleplaying with branching choices and immense scope.
review: Baldur's Gate 3 was an amazing experience. Larian Studios is probably one of the greatest gaming studios ever—they always deliver on their RPGs, and this one takes the cake as the most stunning desktop RPG I've ever played. The story is incredible, the characters have depth, and there are twists and turns with every choice-based action.

title: osu!
summary: A free-to-play rhythm game featuring multiple game modes where players click circles, catch fruit, and hit drum beats to the music.
review: Osu! is probably my favorite video game of all time, just because of the sheer simplicity of the game and how you can visually tell you're getting better or worse as you play. For people who love Guitar Hero, this is that for anime fans. It's the only game where someone's ever said I was 'cracked.'

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
summary: An epic open-world RPG where you explore the vast province of Skyrim as the Dragonborn, with endless quests and mod support.
review: Skyrim takes the cake as a longtime, hands-down Mount Rushmore video game for obvious reasons.

title: The Elder Scrolls Online
summary: An MMORPG set in Tamriel where players explore a vast world, complete quests, and battle alongside others in PvE and PvP content.
review: Elder Scrolls Online was an incredibly fun experience to see Tamriel come to life. I spent several hundred hours in this game and didn't regret a minute.

title: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt
summary: A masterfully crafted open-world RPG following Geralt of Rivia's quest with stunning visuals, deep storytelling, and memorable characters.
review: The Witcher 3 stands out as one of the most stunning story-driven RPGs with one chad of a main character.

title: Marvel Rivals
summary: A free-to-play team-based PvP shooter featuring iconic Marvel superheroes and villains battling in destructible environments.
review: Marvel Rivals was fun while I was playing. I seriously thought it was going to overtake Overwatch, but until they get their matchmaking system figured out, I don't think that's going to happen. However, it is fun to swing around playing Spider-Man while listening to 'Self Love.'

title: Path of Exile
summary: A dark fantasy action RPG with deep character customization, endless loot, and complex endgame content for hardcore ARPG fans.
review: Path of Exile is the most classic ARPG I know. It has all of what you'd expect in a dungeon crawler and more—hundreds of hours of gameplay. For anyone who's played an ARPG, this game has a skill forest, not skill trees.

title: Valheim
summary: A brutal exploration and survival game for 1-10 players set in a Norse-inspired purgatory with crafting, building, and epic boss battles.
review: Valheim was probably the most fun I'd had at a game's launch in recent memory. Everyone in my friend group was all playing this together at the same time during a really tough time for everyone. I think I bought two copies for some other people.

title: Dying Light
summary: A first-person action-horror game that blends parkour movement and melee combat in a city overrun by zombies, with a strong emphasis on co-op play.
review: Dying Light was my first step into what I would call a scary game. I don't do scary or spooky—I like well-lit, bright areas for the most part—but I had to check it out for the parkour, and man, was that fun. FPS shooter, parkour, and zombie killing all in one.

title: 7 Days to Die
summary: An open-world survival horror game combining first-person shooting, tower defense, and role-playing in a zombie-infested wasteland.
review: 7 Days to Die was in some ways not even a horror game. I had fun with this one along with a bunch of friends online. It had been in early access for such a long time I never thought it would fully release, but they did it. The real fans have been playing it since long ago.

title: Divinity: Original Sin 2
summary: A critically acclaimed RPG with deep tactical combat, co-op gameplay, and player-driven stories in a rich fantasy world.
review: Divinity: Original Sin 2—how can I be real about this? It is probably my favorite style of video game, and it does everything in it the best. A tactical strategy RPG, this game is THE D&D PC game to play, hands down, not a question. I would even put this over Baldur's Gate 3.

title: Dragon Age: Inquisition
summary: An epic RPG where you lead the Inquisition to restore order to a world in chaos, with deep lore, strategic combat, and memorable companions.
review: Dragon Age: Inquisition was probably the last game I played on Xbox. I had such a great time, though—everything about the game I remember being incredible, especially all the dragons.

title: Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks
summary: An action-adventure beat 'em up that reimagines the classic fighters as a cooperative, story-driven action game.
review: Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks is hands down my favorite Mortal Kombat game ever made, simply for the fact that it's an RPG that allows you to run around as Liu Kang and do fiery bicycle kicks at everybody.

title: Need for Speed: Carbon
summary: An arcade-style street racing game focused on territorial control and drifting, with a memorable soundtrack and cinematic presentation.
review: Need for Speed: Carbon was my favorite racing game ever made. The car I had was the Lotus Elise—it was black with blue accents. I remember it having black flames all over it. I used to play that game on the PS2 every day after school.

title: Pokémon Blue
summary: The classic Game Boy RPG where you capture and train Pokémon to become the champion — one of the pioneering titles in the series.
review: Pokémon Blue—what can I say? I remember getting Charmander every time I started playing, just to see if it was any harder. I remember MissingNo., the glitch Pokémon that you would get if you surfed down where that old man was. If you beat it, I remember you got unlimited Rare Candies or Master Balls if they were in a certain slot, and some crazy glitches would happen if you actually caught the glitch.
